description: Use this tool to find out if you need to send a tax return for the 2022 to 2023 tax year (6 April 2022 to 5 April 2023).

details.body:
Use this tool to find out if you need to send a tax return for the 2022 to 2023 tax year (6 April 2022 to 5 April 2023).

This service is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

The tool will not send your details to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

nodes.body: You may have worked for yourself as a sole trader, a business partner or a director of a limited company - even if you had another job as well. Check if you’re not sure what working for yourself means.
nodes.title: Did you work for yourself between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023?
What was your work status when you worked for yourself?

nodes.body: This is the amount you earned, including any coronavirus (COVID-19) support payments you received, before taking off any expenses.
nodes.title: Did you earn more than £1,000 from working for yourself?

nodes.body:
You’re an off-payroll worker (also sometimes called a contractor) if you provide services to a client through an intermediary such as:

  • your own limited company
  • a partnership
  • a personal service company
  • an individual
nodes.title: Did you work as an ‘off-payroll worker’?
Do you have a student loan?

options.label: Yes, I get some or all of my pension income from a private pension
Yes, a pension from outside the UK

nodes.title: Did you get a pension?

nodes.body: Other income could include money from property or investments.
nodes.title: Do you have any other form of income, apart from your State Pension?

nodes.body:
Income could be from:
- your pension
- salary before tax and pension contributions
- any taxable benefits (such as a company car)
- property or investments
nodes.title: What was your total income for the year?

options.label: No, but someone claimed it for a child that lived with me at the time and they contributed at least as much as me towards the child’s upkeep
No, I do not have children or did not claim

nodes.title: Did you claim Child Benefit?

nodes.body: This includes renting out a property or using your home as a short-term holiday let.
nodes.title: Did any of your income come from UK property or land?

nodes.body:
To work this out, add up your total income from property or land. That’s your gross earnings. To get your net earnings, deduct any allowable expenses - for example, maintenance and repair costs.

The rules are different if you’re a non-resident landlord.

options.label: More than £2,500 net (or more than £10,000 gross)

nodes.title: How much did you get from UK property or land (gross and net)?

nodes.body:
Income from savings and investments includes:

  • savings interest
  • money from bare trusts
  • interest in possession trusts

options.label: Yes, I got more than £10,000 from savings and investments
Yes, I got more than £10,000 from share dividends

nodes.title: Did you get more than £10,000 from dividends or savings and investments?

options.label: Income from outside the UK (includes pensions)
£2,500 or more in commission or cash in hand payments
A payment or charge on a private pension
A Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (SEISS) grant

nodes.title: Do you need to pay tax on any of the following?

nodes.body: Ask your pension provider if you’re not sure.

options.label: Money in my pension pots above my annual or lifetime allowance
Unauthorised payments from a pension scheme

nodes.title: Which pension payment or charge do you need to tell HMRC about?

nodes.body:
You usually have to pay Capital Gains Tax when you sell or give away:

  • most personal possessions worth £6,000 or more (apart from your car)
  • any other assets, such as shares or a holiday home
nodes.title: Do you need to pay any Capital Gains Tax?

nodes.body:
The positions that affect how you’re taxed are:

  • religious minister
  • Lloyd’s underwriter
  • examiner, exam moderator or invigilator
  • share fisherman
nodes.title: Did you hold a position that affects how you’re taxed?

nodes.body:
The positions that affect how you’re taxed are:

  • religious minister
  • Lloyd’s underwriter
  • examiner, exam moderator or invigilator
  • share fisherman
nodes.title: Did you hold a position that affects how you’re taxed?

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you need to send a return for 2022 to 2023 because you’re a self-employed sole trader.

What to do next

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you need to send a return for 2022 to 2023 because you’re a partner or partnership.

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you do not need to send a return for 2022 to 2023 because your only income is the State Pension. 

If your State Pension payments have gone over your Personal Allowance, HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) will write and tell you what you owe.

You do not need to confirm to HMRC that you will not be sending a return - unless they asked you to send one.

You can choose to send a return (for example, to claim some allowances or income tax reliefs) – find out more about sending a return for any other reason. 

If HMRC asked you to send a return 

If HMRC wrote to you asking you to send a return but you believe you do not need to, you’ll need to contact them and explain this. They may need to update their records.

Tell HMRC you no longer need to send a tax return.
nodes.title: You do not need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you need to send a return for 2022 to 2023.

What to do next

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
You or your partner may need to send a return for 2022 to 2023 to pay the High Income Child Benefit Charge.

What to do next

Use the Child Benefit tax calculator to work out if you or your partner have to pay the charge.

If you or your partner do have to pay, then:

  1. If you’ve never sent a tax return, register now - allow 10 working days to register (21 working days if you’re abroad).

  2. Check how to send a tax return and when you or your partner has to send it.

  3. Send the tax return.

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

You can contact HMRC if you need help.
nodes.title: You or your partner (if you have one) may need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
You need to send a return if you owe Income Tax on a trust for 2022 to 2023.

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
You need to send a return if you owe tax on foreign income for 2022 to 2023.

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you need to send a return for 2022 to 2023.

What to do next

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.

When you fill in your return, make sure you tell HMRC about the position you held that affects how you’re taxed.
nodes.title: You need to send a Self Assessment tax return

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you have Capital Gains Tax to report.

What to do next

You must register for Self Assessment if you’ve not sent a tax return before.  

It can take up to 10 working days (21 working days if you’re abroad) for your registration to be confirmed. 

If you’ve registered before but did not send a return last year, sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

If you’re already registered, send your tax return by the deadline.
nodes.title: You may need to send a Self Assessment tax return to pay Capital Gains Tax

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, you do not need to send a return for 2022 to 2023.

You do not need to confirm to HMRC that you will not be sending a return - unless they asked you to send one.

You can choose to send a return (for example, to claim some allowances or income tax reliefs) – find out more about sending a return for any other reason.

If HMRC asked you to send a return

If HMRC wrote to you asking you to send a return but you believe you no longer need to, you’ll need to contact them and explain this. For example, if you have stopped working for yourself, HMRC might not be aware – you’ll need to tell them so they can update their records.

Tell HMRC you no longer need to send a tax return.

If you had untaxed income

You must tell HMRC if you had:

  • more than £2,000 income from share dividends
  • between £1,000 and £2,500 in any other untaxed income, such as commission or money from renting out a property

You do not need to send a return for this. You can either:

  • check your Income Tax and go to ‘Tell us about a change’
  • call HMRC
nodes.title: You do not need to send a Self Assessment tax return

This guidance covers:

  • how to register
  • filing your return
  • paying your bill
contact_form_links.title: Find out more about Self Assessment tax returns

details.description: Contact HMRC for advice on Self Assessment and to change your personal details

phone_numbers.description:
Call HMRC for advice on Self Assessment.

Problems using HMRC’s online services

Contact HMRC’s online services helpdesk if you:

  • have problems submitting your tax return online
  • have lost your online service user name or password
  • get any error messages in your online account or on HMRC forms

Before you call

If you have a National Insurance number and Self Assessment Unique Taxpayer Reference have them with you.

This helpline uses speech recognition software, so you will be asked why you are calling HMRC. If you cannot use speech recognition software, find out how to get help from HMRC if you need extra support.

This helpline may also ask you some security questions. Make sure your personal details and address are up to date in your personal tax account or you could fail telephone security. If you do not have a personal tax account, you can create one before you check your details.

HMRC may ask if you want to add voice identification to your account. You can find out more in the Voice Identification Privacy Notice.
phone_numbers.open_hours:
Monday to Friday: 8am to 6pm

Closed on weekends and bank holidays.

Get help from HMRC if you need extra support.
phone_numbers.title: Self Assessment Helpline

post_addresses.description:
Write to HMRC at this address with all Self Assessment queries except if you want to make a complaint about HMRC.

You do not need to include a street name, city name or PO box when writing to this address.

Couriers should use a different address.
